DOC.HEAD: Titan Launch Delayed For the Ninth Time
DOC.TEXT: Martin Marietta was forced Saturday to postpone for the ninth time the first commercial launch of its Titan 3 rocket, once again because of high-altitude crosswinds streaking up to 102 mph. The rocket is to boost communications satellites into orbit for the Japanese Communications Satellite Co. and the British Ministry of Defence. Liftoff originally was scheduled Dec. 7, but a technical problem delayed one launch effort and the rest were scrubbed because of high winds. The winds had been acceptable earlier Saturday, but the speed increased throughout the day as a series of weather balloons shot into the sky. When the countdown reached the five-minute mark, the launch team held it for 50 minutes while officials assessed last-minute balloon data. It showed 102 mph winds at 34,790 feet, about 30 mph too high for a safe Titan passage. A 10th attempt was scheduled for 7:07 p.m. Sunday night.
